FacilityName: Cargill Turkey Products, St. Pauls, N.C.
ParentCompanyName: Cargill Turkey Products, St. Pauls, N.C.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
Cargill Turkey Products chemical accident prevention and emergency response policies for ammonia refrigeration involve the development of this Risk Management Program and Plan (RMP) which has a primary objective of preventing an accidental release of ammonia, and minimizing the consequences of a release should one occur.  Written policies exist to address written policy requirements from OSHA (i.e. chemical hazard communication, lockout tagout, confined space entry, emergency action plans, hot work, line breaking and PSM) in addition a written contractor safety program is in place.

Senior managemnt has appointed a PSM team to monitor and maintain overall compliance with both OSHA's PSM and EPA's RMP program.

Facility and Regulated Substances:
The stationary source subject to this RMP is Cargill's turkey processing facility located in St. Pauls, N.C.  The regulated substance that is the subject of this RMP is anhydrous ammonia used in the refrigeration system.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps:
In accordance with RMP regulations, the general accidental release prevention program for this facility is ammonia refrigeration system is comprised of the following components:  process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, operator training, procedures for maintaining mechanical integrity, procedures for managing system changes, pre-start up safety review procedures, procedures for investigating release incidents and hot work permit portocols.  This program was developed with the participation the the affected employees, and is periodically audited for compliance as required by the RMP regulations.  In addition, the facility has in place procedures for notifying contractors and their employees of the hazards of the system.  Chemical specific prevention steps are included within the program, including engineering and administrative

control designed to prevent and minimize accidental release.

Five year history:
In the previous five years, this facility has had no accidental releases.

Emergency Response Program:
This facility has developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) which addresses accidental releases of hazardous substances and has coordinated with the LEPC and EHC. 

Planned changes to Improve Safety:
The most recent process hazard analysis was performed on 1/1/04.  This facility continues to monitor and maintain it's PSM/RMP program through an organized PSM team chartered to ensure all elements of the PSM/RMP program are in place.
